title: Biliary Atresia
diagnosis_topic: Progressive fibro-obliterative disease of the extrahepatic bile ducts
setup_script: “A 6-week-old infant presents with persistent jaundice since birth, dark urine, and pale stools. The parents report poor weight gain. On physical exam, the infant is jaundiced with hepatomegaly and a palpable spleen. How would you proceed with this patient?”

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 85/45 mmHg, HR 140 bpm, RR 30/min, Temp 37.1 °C.
Jaundice noted at 2 weeks; poor weight gain; no family history of liver disease.
Jaundiced skin and sclera, enlarged firm liver, spleen palpable 2 cm below costal margin.
Direct bilirubin 8 mg/dL, AST/ALT mildly elevated, gamma-glutamyl transferase markedly elevated, PT prolonged.
Absent gallbladder, triangular cord sign at porta hepatis consistent with biliary atresia.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident schedules hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid (HIDA) scan after phenobarbital priming
dynamic_flow.reply: No excretion of tracer into intestine confirming biliary obstruction.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates nutritional support and fat-soluble vitamin supplementation
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient tolerates feeds and avoids nutritional deficiencies.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident consults pediatric surgery for Kasai portoenterostomy
dynamic_flow.reply: Surgery recommended before 8 weeks of age to improve bile flow.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays surgery beyond 3 months
dynamic_flow.reply: Kasai procedure less effective; higher likelihood of needing liver transplant.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident evaluates for associated anomalies
dynamic_flow.reply: Cardiac anomalies, polysplenia, or situs inversus may be present.
Biliary drainage achieved, jaundice gradually improves.
Prophylactic antibiotics, ursodeoxycholic acid, monitoring for cholangitis and progressive liver disease.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident counsels parents about long-term outcomes
dynamic_flow.reply: Many patients require liver transplantation despite initial surgery; transplant evaluation discussed.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident fails to initiate timely surgical referral
dynamic_flow.reply: Infant develops progressive cirrhosis, portal hypertension, and liver failure.

critical_decision_points: Early recognition of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and cholestatic jaundice
Diagnostic imaging with ultrasound and HIDA scan
Timely referral for Kasai portoenterostomy before 8 weeks of age
Supportive management with nutrition and vitamin supplementation
Counseling families on prognosis and potential need for liver transplantation
